results.content: This has been a fantastic Materialize Course for me. I was already familiar with the framework but I didn't know all of its components because (a) when you're new to programming, there are names, words and terminology you've never heard of so you would never think to search for it and (b) this course is a great reference point as well as practice. My one criticism is so far every other course I've purchased, I've been able to get my questions answered in the Q&A section and I have not received one answer in the last week or so for this course. Brad is clear and I can easily learn from him. I took a leap of faith and purchased several of his courses. Im just hoping that support will be there when it is called upon in the Q&A section.

results.content: I've been following Brad's YouTube channel for the past year.  He always offers in-depth and easy to follow videos free of charge, and mentioned that he also had some Udemy courses available.  I wanted to support him, so I immediately grabbed this course (along with a few others).  However, I was blown away by how excellent this course truly was!  It was a great idea to start off with a sandbox section and then move to the actual projects, as it allows you to take concepts you are familiar with and put them in a professional-looking website.  I also plan to use the sandbox project as reference material when I start working on my own sites.  Brad's lectures are easy-to-follow and he is great at explaining each of the Materialize components in-depth.  I also love that he doesn't edit out his mistakes as it's helpful (and realistic in a programming environment) to see how he figures out small errors.  Overall, I would definitely recommend this course and look forward to taking his other Udemy courses in the future.

results.content:
Brad has a ton of pro-quality and free information on YouTube where I first found him.  However this course is well-worth the extra cost for his up-to-date and relevant content.  His steady and confident pace of the video is consistent throughout the course and his style is professional and genuine.  

I find that Brad's course is an excellent companion to incorporate Materialize in front-end workflow and being a relative newcomer to the field, I truly appreciate his coverage in the course in other relevant areas, such as accommodating different clients w/ his various themes, broadening the framework w/ jQuery, and an introduction in SASS.

As he mentions in the video about those additional materials not becoming too distracting away from Materialize, I believe he did an amazing job.  

Overall, I highly recommend this course and I am excited to see his next topic.

results.content: Overall Brad does a great job of explaining Materialize and as usual his project-based approach is a great way to learn. The downside is that Google has changed the way you interact with the Google Maps API since the course was published and Materialize 1.00 has been release that eliminates the dependency on JQuery so the course needs to be updated. Having said that, the course does provide a good grounding in understanding how Materialize works and can be used to design web sites.

results.content:
I really love this framework but it seems a little out of date and not popular if you compare it with bootstrap but It gets the job done and I really like it. 

The course requires a minor refresh since I found my self check way too often the materialize website (1.0.0) trying to fix jquery/javascript dependencies. I came back to this after months since it bugged me that I had it at 97% completed in my basket. I would replace Project 5 since it was the worst one for me. ScrollFire is not part of materialize 1.0.0 so all you get is in the Q&A someone who provide the complete solution with a workaround which made the course finish on a weak note. This really gets you up and running with this framework.

results.content: Excellent Course!  Brad's clear, matter of fact, voice is easy to follow - at different speeds.  Coming from no CSS framework experience, I feel like I've gotten a working grasp of Materialize, valuable practice with Emmet, plus a good introduction to the lovely Sass.  I like how we first went through an overview of Materialize basics to gain some perspective on its many features. The provided templates allowed me to focus on the Materialize topic at hand, and provided a sandbox to try other ideas.  The resulting pages serve nicely for later reference.  Useful also were the best practices tips - more of these in future courses is my only request.  By attempting to build each lecture part before following the instructions, I feel like I got the most I could out of the course.  Thanks Brad for doing such a great job!

results.content: A very useful course. Brad helps you create some amazing example projects - and explains everything well. It is well-paced and the resources provided are very helpful as well. Though I completed this a bit late ( considering there is a new version with some changes in the implementation as explained in their documentation) - this course has been highly helpful and also makes you understand how to refer to the documentation and the widgets being used and update your code accordingly if you would like. results.content:
This course is outdated!
The course covers an older alpha version of Materialize!

Version 1.0.0 of Materialize has been out for some time and has changed a couple of things. 
Going through some of sections of this course cost me some nerves and patience, because I wasn't sure if I was doing something wrong or the instructor forgot to update the course video.

Most of the changes are not trivial to fix and they can take 10-15 min. each to solve. At this point, one might as well use the materialize documentation instead of going through these videos.

I'm willing to give this course a 5 Star, once it's been overhauled.

Update: 
So, I've gone through the whole course and posted my solutions to each section and project. I decided to solve many of the problems of the outdated code. One thing I couldn't test if it worked was the Google Maps API, which Google decided to lock behind a billing system. Others such as the fade in animation for two of the last projects took me some time to adjust, but I managed to get it to work.

Other than that, this course will definitely be perfect  for anyone who wants to create front-end solutions for websites and web apps, once it gets updated.

This is another first-rate Udemy course from Brad Traversy. As ever, he brings a wealth of personal experience and in-depth knowledge and puts this into real-world practice. The course projects are fun and  great examples of Materialize CSS in action. The Sandbox that Brad provides is a superb introduction  to the main features of the library and I will keep it as a fantastic resource.

results.content: The course is over a pre-1.0 release of MaterializeCSS.com. The course states that course will be updated to 1.0 when released. MaterializeCSS.com as of July 21, 2018 shows 1.0.0-rc.2 as current release. Course has not been updated. I feel let down and outdated in first few videos. The Google Maps API is outdated and does not work as detailed in applicable project. The instructor used Google Maps JavaScript API in a Materialize CSS course which Google charges for now with each Maps JavaScript API call. A more appropriate and free use for this Materialize CSS course would have been Google Maps Embed API. If instructor wants to toss in optional JavaScript at least keep it updated. Overall the course had good amount of beginner exercises and projects. I prefer less copy and pasting in beginner courses and more manual editing because it is additional practice for users. I did like that instructor included mistakes in coding and figured out issue in course. These exercises generally help beginners.

results.content:
Excellent course on Materialize, highly recommended.

As always, Brad is a good instructor and the course is well organized and prepared. The pace is fast and everything is to the point. Very hands-on.

Materialize is a useful CSS library and this course gave me a very good understanding of the whole thing. Also, the 5 projects are great as exercises for using the library to build real website UIs.

Good call including Sass in the final project, too.

BTW, as of now, the course uses an outdated version of Materialize. This is no big deal. As long as you follow along with the old version of the library you'll be fine.

results.content: An excellent course to take to learn more about CSS.  Along with Brad's Bootstrap course, these are the tools you should know if you are serious about UX/UI design.  The projects are practical and can be used in a variety of apps.  Note however that Project 5 (Galappear) seems to be outdated as far as the new Materialize version so some of the HTML will need to be tweaked (i.e., reference the Materialize website to make it work or see the Q&A for the up to date solution).  However that's not a crticism of this course or the instructor.  Software versions are constantly evolving so noobs should be referencing the Materialize website to actually learn the stuff and git 'er done.  I recommend this course.
